description:
Strongyloides ratti is a species of nematode (roundworm) that primarily infects rats and other rodents. It is an important model organism in the study of strongyloidiasis, a parasitic infection caused by Strongyloides species.

Strongyloides ratti has a complex life cycle that involves both free-living and parasitic stages. The free-living stages include the infective third-stage larvae (L3) and the adult male and female worms that reproduce in the environment. The parasitic stage involves the infection of the host, where the L3 larvae penetrate the skin and migrate to the small intestine, where they mature into adult female worms that produce eggs.

The eggs hatch in the intestine, and the resulting larvae can either develop into the free-living stages or directly infect the host through a process called autoinfection. This ability to perpetuate the infection within the host is a key characteristic of Strongyloides infections, and it can lead to chronic and potentially life-threatening infections in immunocompromised individuals.

Strongyloides ratti is widely used in research to study the host-parasite interactions, immune responses, and the development of new treatments for strongyloidiasis. It serves as a valuable model for understanding the biology and pathogenesis of this important parasitic infection.
